metadata.titleEn: Whole-rock and mineral geochemical compositions of  leucogranite and pegmatite in Xiaru dome, Xizang, China
metadata.description: including muscovite granite with the occurrence of wolframite,muscovite granite with Nb⁃Ta⁃W oxide minerals and pegmatite with the occurrence of columbite⁃group minerals. Meanwhile,the typical muscovite granite without any rare ⁃ metal minerals (barren muscovite granite hereafter) is selected for comparison. Major and trace elements of whole rock geochemistry, the occurrence, major and trace elements of rock forming minerals and accessory minerals are comparable. The whole rock compositions were analyzed by XRF adn ICP-MS. The chemical compositions of minerals were analyzed by EMP and LA-ICPMS. It is suggested that whole ⁃ rock composition is indicative for the fluid activity,while the composition characteristics of muscovite,tourmaline and garnet are indicative for the process and degree of the magma evolution.
metadata.instructions: Data stored in Excel format.File name called "WRMajTr", on behalf of the whole rock of main trace elements, file name, called "MusMajTra", on behalf of the white mica main trace elements data, file name "GarMajTra", on behalf of the garnet main trace elements data, file name "TurMajTra", on behalf of tourmaline main trace elements data, file name "ZrnMajTra", on behalf of the main elements zircon data.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific characteristics of granites and pegmatites are indicated by whole-rock geochemical data in this domain?
Feature Specification.Answer: fluid activity, major and trace element compositions, precision better than 10%

Quantification.Question: How many different rock samples were analyzed using XRF and ICP-MS for their major and trace element compositions?
Quantification.Answer: The original answer does not provide a numerical value for the number of rock samples analyzed. Therefore, there is no quantifiable information to extract or refine.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about fluid activity and magmatic evolution processes from the geochemical data collected using XRF, ICP-MS, EMPA, and LA-ICPMS techniques?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical data collected suggests that whole-rock compositions of granite-pegmatite are more effective indicators of fluid activity, while the compositional characteristics of muscovite, tourmaline, and garnet more effectively indicate magmatic evolution processes and degrees of evolution.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes variations in the geochemical data collected from samples of muscovite granite and pegmatite in the Xiaru Dome, and how do these variations affect the interpretation of fluid activity and magmatic evolution?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations in geochemical data can be caused by differences in the composition of the muscovite granite and pegmatite, which may include the presence of mineralization indicators such as black tungsten ore and niobium-tantalum-tungsten oxides. These changes can affect the interpretation of fluid activity and magmatic evolution because the whole-rock composition suggests fluid activity, while the composition of minerals like muscovite, tourmaline, and garnet better indicates the magmatic evolution process and degree.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using XRF and ICP-MS for obtaining whole-rock major and trace element data in terms of data accuracy and reliability?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using XRF and ICP-MS for obtaining whole-rock major and trace element data can result in high accuracy and reliability, with precision better than 10%. This allows for effective indication of fluid activity in granite-pegmatite whole-rock compositions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What techniques and instruments are utilized for collecting geochemical data from mineral samples in the context of studying granite and pegmatite rock formations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The geochemical data collection involves using X-ray Fluorescence (XRF) and Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) for obtaining whole-rock major and trace element data. Electron Microprobe Analysis (EMPA) and Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LA-ICPMS) are employed to acquire the major and trace element data of minerals. These methods provide precision better than 10%.
